opener.subtitle: Why California’s Water Is Unique
opener.p1: All living things need water to survive.
opener.p2: However, in California, most of our water falls far from where most people live, work, and farm.

precipitation.title: Where and When Precipitation Falls
precipitation.p1: The vast majority of California’s rain and snow falls in the northern part of the state.
precipitation.p2: Like clockwork, we expect nearly all of our precipitation in winter — a short period lasting less than 100 days.
precipitation.p3: What’s less predictable is how much rain and snow we get in any year.
precipitation.p4: It varies by a lot, especially the farther south you go.

variability.p1: California farmers, anglers, and water buffs agonize over flip-flop between wet and dry years.
variability.p2: We worry about droughts, then floods, then droughts — back and forth.
variability.p3: California rarely experiences an “average” year of precipitation.
variability.p4: Yet we need water every day of the year, all across the state.

snowpack.title: The Snowpack Advantage: Nature’s Water Storage
snowpack.p1: At high elevations in California’s mountains, abundant snow isn’t just fun or pretty.
snowpack.p2: It is a frozen water tower, storing water in the mountains.
snowpack.p3: As snow melts in late spring, it feeds rivers and keeps many flowing through our dry summer.

flow.title: Water Flows from the Sierra to the Delta
flow.p1: Across our planet, gravity drives freshwater flow from mountains to the sea.
flow.p2: Within California, snowmelt drains from the Sierra Nevada mountains into small mountain creeks.
flow.p3: Some water seeps underground, replenishing aquifers.

valley.p3: Floodwaters infiltrate into soils and refresh groundwater.
valley.p4: In the dry summer, the groundwater then feeds rivers with a cool source of water.

delta.p2: For thousands of years, California's water supported a remarkable diversity of life.
delta.p3: Central Valley rivers teamed with salmon.
delta.p4: Its wetlands hosted millions of migratory birds.
delta.transition: California's water system looks very different today.

economy.title: A growing economy demanded more water
economy.p1: The Gold Rush brought thousands of European settlers to California.
economy.p2: Miners diverted rivers to find gold.

irrigation.p1: Settlers built canals, drained wetlands, and pumped groundwater to expand Central Valley farms.
irrigation.p2: As the scale of irrigation increased, agriculture became a powerhouse of the state's economy.

drinking.p1: Growing communities and towns needed reliable water for drinking, sanitation and businesses.
drinking.p2: Leaders of major coastal communities found ways to import water from distant sources.
drinking.p3: It required water rights and major investments as water infrastructure began to crisscross the state.
